articles.author: Manav Lahariya
articles.description:
How We Fixed Our Shipping Integration Chaos with Ditto: A Fulfillment Use Case in E-Commerce


The modern e-commerce supply chain moves fast‚Äîbut integrating with third-party shipping services doesn‚Äôt. We learned this the hard way, juggling broken APIs, unreliable sandbox environments, and zero visibility into request/response flows.
üì¶ The Problem: Shipping APIs Were Slowing Us Down


We‚Äôre an e-commerce platform managing thousands of orders per day. Shipping is critical to our customer experience. But integrating with new carriers or updating old integrations was painful:
No reliable sandboxes: Most shipping providers had inconsistent or outdated test environments.
Delayed feedback: Every change needed a full deploy, then a real API hit, and then debugging based on logs.
Hard to test edge cases: Simulating scenarios like "address not found", "label unavailable", or "customs hold" was impossible.
Cross-team bottlenecks: Backend, QA, and devOps were constantly waiting on each other just to test a single flow.
Every integration took weeks longer than it should have, with late nights spent tailing logs and replaying requests.
üöÄ Enter Ditto: Mock APIs That Work Like the Real Thing


We deployed Ditto internally as a drop-in mock server platform. Think of it like Postman‚Äîbut private, flexible, and built for teams.
1. Created realistic mocks for all shipping APIs
2. Collaborative interface
3. Integrated with CI/CD
4. Zero downtime testing
üè≠ Use Case: Fulfillment ‚Üí Shipping in E-Commerce


Here‚Äôs a specific example:
Scenario:
Pain Point:

üí∞ ROI: Faster Delivery Times, Happier Devs, and Lower Costs


After adopting Ditto, our team saw immediate benefits:

We estimate that Ditto saved over 200 hours of dev time in the first quarter alone. More importantly, it helped us ship (pun intended) with confidence.
APIs should never be a bottleneck. With Ditto, they‚Äôre not.

articles.description:
When working with relational databases and transactions, consistency is key. But what happens when multiple transactions access and modify the same data at the same time?
This is where isolation levels come into play.
In this blog post, you'll learn:
What isolation levels are
Common concurrency problems
ANSI SQL isolation levels
How different databases implement them
How to configure them in Spring Boot/JPA
Transaction isolation defines how and when the changes made by one transaction become visible to other transactions.
Imagine two users updating the same bank account at the same time ‚Äî you wouldn‚Äôt want one user‚Äôs withdrawal to overwrite the other‚Äôs deposit, right?
Isolation levels determine how concurrent access is handled and protect against issues like:
Dirty Reads
Non-Repeatable Rea‚Ä¶
articles.title: üßµ Understanding Database Isolation Levels: A Developer‚Äôs Guide to Consistent Transactions

What Is Artificial Intelligence?


Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to the ability of machines or computer programs to mimic human intelligence. This includes learning from data, recognizing patterns, understanding language, solving problems, and making decisions.
AI systems are designed to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence ‚Äî from simple actions like sorting emails to complex tasks like diagnosing diseases or driving autonomous cars.
AI is already embedded in tools we use daily:
Recommendation engines on Netflix or Spotify
Smart assistants like Siri and Alexa
Fraud detection in banking apps
Language translation tools
As developers, understanding AI means being equipped for the next evolution of software development ‚Äî one where data drives logic and automation.

First things first‚ÄîDevOps isn‚Äôt a tool. Or a job title. Or a silver bullet that shoots bugs on sight.

It‚Äôs a mindset. A culture. A magical handshake between developers and operations folks who used to operate like divorced parents trying to co-parent a flaky app.

At its core, DevOps breaks down silos and brings teams together around shared goals: faster delivery, fewer bugs, and happier humans.
Before DevOps, our team treated deployments like rare celestial events‚Äîonce a month, visible only under perfect conditions.

We‚Äôd brace ourselves for a three-hour rollout followed by a three-day bug hunt.

Now? We ship daily. Sometimes multiple times a day. And not because we enjoy chaos‚Äîbut because we‚Äôve built pipelines, automation, and trust.
Let‚Äôs talk tools.

CI/CD‚ÄîContinuous Integration and C‚Ä¶

articles.author: Ahmed Niazy
articles.description:
Git is a distributed version control system (DVCS) created by Linus Torvalds in 2005 to manage the Linux kernel‚Äôs source code. Unlike centralized systems, Git keeps a complete history of your project on every developer‚Äôs machine, making it easy to revert, branch, and merge changes no matter your workflow.
Below is a reorganized, step-by-step guide to the 50 Git commands you‚Äôll use most often, grouped by category. You‚Äôll find concise explanations, usage examples, and tips so you can copy-and-paste as you learn.
Before you start, tell Git who you are:
# View all settings (name, email, cache, editor, etc.)
git config -l

# Set your name (appears in commits)
git config --global user.name "Your Name"

# Set your email (appears in commits)
git config --global user.email "you@example.com"

# Cach‚Ä¶
articles.title: Git: 50 Essential Commands for Everyday Workflow

articles.author: Tamilselvan K
articles.description:
As part of my front-end development journey, I recently took on a small but meaningful project: cloning the ILUGC (Indian Linux Users Group Chennai) website. It might not be flashy or complex, but this project taught me a lot about how simple design and clean structure can still offer great learning opportunities.
Why ILUGC? üîç
The ILUGC website is a minimal, text-heavy page with a focus on functionality over fancy design. That made it a great candidate for practice ‚Äî no distractions, just pure HTML and CSS work. I wanted to challenge myself to recreate it from scratch, paying attention to layout, structure, and styling.
What I Learned üìò‚ú®
Semantic HTML matters: Using the right tags made the page easier to read and maintain.
CSS structure and layout: I practiced layout alignment using Flexbox and gained confidence in styling text and links.
Attention to detail: Small details like spacing, font size, and padding make a big difference in the final look.
Mobile responsiveness: Even for a simple page, I learned how important it is to make the layout adapt to different screen sizes.
My Takeaway üéØ
This project reminded me that we don't always need big frameworks or advanced tools to learn. Sometimes, going back to basics and working on clean, straightforward pages helps solidify core concepts.
It also gave me a sense of accomplishment ‚Äî not from building something brand new, but from understanding how real-world pages are structured and bringing that into my own learning process.
What's Next? üöÄ
I‚Äôm currently continuing my journey through front-end development, with plans to dive into JavaScript next. Eventually, I aim to become a full-stack developer with a strong grasp of both the front-end and back-end.
Thanks for reading! If you're just starting out too, I highly recommend trying to clone simple websites. It‚Äôs a great way to learn by doing! üå±
articles.title: Day-16 I Cloned the ILUGC Web Page ‚Äì Here's What I Learned üåêüíª

Semler Scientific, a medical device company, purchased of $50 million worth of Bitcoin between May 13 and May 22, bringing the market value of the company‚Äôs Bitcoin (BTC) holdings to $474.4 million, keeping it within the top 13 of BTC Treasury companies.
According to a May 23 disclosure, Semler bought a total of 455 BTC for an average purchase price of $109,801. To buy the Bitcoin, Semler Scientific used proceeds from an at-the-market stock offering program. So far, the company has sold roughly 3 million shares of common stock for net proceeds of $115 million.
Semler Scientific‚Äôs shares have fallen 1.36% on the same day as the disclosure, though the decrease in its share price is largely in line with the Nasdaq‚Äôs performance. That index, which follows top tech stocks, is down 1% on the day.
Semler Scientific share price. Source: Google Finance
In its Q1 2025 earnings report released on May 13, the company revealed a 44% drop in revenue year-over-year. Despite the claimed success of its Bitcoin treasury plan, Semler Scientific‚Äôs shares have dropped 18% in 2025, according to Google Finance.
Bitcoin treasury companies, or companies that traditionally sell equity or issue debt to buy BTC, had been drawing the interest of investors looking for exposure to Bitcoin price fluctuations.
Michael Saylor's Strategy debuted its BTC reserve in August 2020, when it started purchasing Bitcoin. Bitcoin is up 181.6% year to date, while Semler Scientific shares rose 53% since announcing the BTC approach in May 2024.

Opinion by: Grigore Ro»ôu, founder and chief executive officer of Pi Squared
For some, the audacity of questioning the primacy of blockchain in Web3 is borderline heretical. The idea that decentralization and progress could exist without blockchains seems absurd to those who built careers around Bitcoin, Ethereum, and their descendants. Given blockchain's well-documented scaling limits, however, there is an argument to be made that Web3 doesn't actually need blockchains to thrive. Instead, it requires payment systems and verifiable settlement systems that are super fast. Blockchains are just one way to achieve that, not the only way.

Understanding the Curve Finance DNS hijacking            
            
                
On May 12, 2025, at 20:55 UTC, hackers hijacked the ‚Äú.fi‚Äù domain name system (DNS) of Curve Finance after managing to access the registrar. They began sending its users to a malicious website, attempting to drain their wallets. This was the second attack on Curve Finance‚Äôs infrastructure in a week.
Users were directed to a website that was a non-functional decoy, designed only to trick users into providing wallet signatures. The hack hadn‚Äôt breached the protocol‚Äôs smart contracts and was limited to the DNS layer.

‚ÄúThis means assets aren‚Äôt rehypothecated, reused, or loaned out to generate yield,‚Äù Ledn co-founder and CEO Adam Reeds told Cointelegraph.
